learning_outcomes.description: Evaluate factors affecting pest ecology, with special emphasise on weeds.
Estimate the impact of different pests on crops, with special emphasise on weeds.
Compare and contrast different pest control measures.
Propose integrated pest management strategies to manage pests in different scenarios.
Synthesise information from plant protection literature.

assessments.task_description:
An online weeds exam will be held on 23 March 2026 commencing 3:00 PM approx. Further instructions and details will be provided on Blackboard closer to the date.

The exam will consist of multiple-choice and/or short answer questions and will contribute 25% to the final grade.

The exam will be an on-campus exam, held during a scheduled on-campus session. Have your UQ student ID card available for all your exams.

Students are responsible for ensuring a stable internet connection while undertaking an online exam.

Troubleshooting – if students experience any technical difficulties during the exam: 

  • Do not close the browser window. 
  • Contact AskUs immediately: support.my.uq.edu.au/app/chat/chat_launch_lib – if the technical issue cannot be resolved, ask for a copy of the chat. 
  • Document the problem – if you receive an error message or similar, take a copy of the message, note the time/date of the problem, which web browser you used, exactly what you were doing at the time and any other relevant information. 
  • Email your course coordinator (copy in AGFS Admin – agriculture@enquire.uq.edu.au) with your documented evidence and a copy of the AskUs chat. Any delays in this communication being received may impact the advice that could be provided to you.

This assessment task must be completed in person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
Students will develop a one-page poster targeted at growers, focusing on a key crop pest issue (weeds, insects, pathogens, etc.). The poster must clearly describe the pest, the symptoms it causes, and its impact on crop production. Students should also present practical, evidence-based management options so the poster serves as a useful extension resource for growers.

Posters are an A4 proportion pictorial/verbal summary of the topic. Orientation is PORTRAIT.

A rubric will be made available to students on blackboard.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which AI will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI tools.

assessments.task_description:
Students will deliver a presentation in the 3 minute thesis (3MT) format, with a strict time limit of three minutes per presentation. Students must select a target pest (weed, disease, or insect) and prepare a single slide on its biology and/or management. The presentation must be completed in person, with no more than one slide allowed. The event will be held on May 18 and 25, 2025, and all presentations will be recorded. Students will be assigned one of the two dates for their MT3 assessment.

This assessment task must be completed in person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

The blackboard site will provide detailed information on the criteria and marking for different components (for example, content, delivery, quality, etc.).
